title.narrative: Transgenerational equity and sustainable technologies (TEST) for agricultural waste to energy

description.narrative: Goal 1 - Physico-chemical technologies Goal 2 - Bioresources from wastes Goal 3 - Biotechnologies and their limitations Goal 4 - Empower women workforce in the energy sector Goal 5 - Case studies from the Netherlands
Staff members and teaching assistants from Chiang Mai University, Thailand

participating-org.narrative: IHE Delft Institute for Water Education
IHE Delft Institute for Water Education

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: TEST-Waste to energy, credit: Eldon Rene
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities . Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the grant award letter, the dates for submission of the annual reports are mentioned. In case of a three-year project, between 5-7 reports are obligatory. The first report (0) is a very short report which focuses on specific conditions and/or recommendations in the grant. There is no need to report on progress in achieving outputs and outcomes, which is done in the first annual report. As annex to the report 0, the consortium agreements between the partners should be submitted. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please provide a global overview of the project progress **per output**. To what extent have they been achieved? Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women
B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 14-04-2021: An evaluation of the TMT was carried out and ALL the alumni satisfaction was VERY GOOD.

title.narrative: B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication

comment.narrative: 14-04-2021: It will be nice if a standard online TMT course evaluation form is provided by OKP-Nuffic. In this manner, all the awarded TMTs can be evaluated with the same criteria. For this TMT = All the participants mentioned that they have gained new skills and knowledge.

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 14-04-2021: This was NOT confirmed or verified later. We assume, by now (April 2021) that at least 30% of the TMT participants would have applied this knowledge in their teaching and/or research developments.

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative: 31-03-2021: 1) Only 15 female staff members attended the training due to the low number of female staff in the Environmental Engineering department, CMU. However, female staff members and PhD candidates from the Environmental Engineering department got the first priority to attend this training. Moreover, the female staffs from other related fields were also invited and got the first priority to attend this training. Information about the TMT was sent by email and as a poster/flyer to all head of the related departments of Chiang Mai University (CMU). The TMT facilitated good networking opportunity for IHE Delft staffs and also CMU staffs with other universities in Thailand. 2) Prof. Susanne Rotter, one of the trainers, could not attend the training in person from Berlin. Therefore, she joined by SKYPE. 3) Eldon Raj from IHE Delft also conducted a half day scientific writing workshop for PhD students of CMU and it was attended by ~15 female students.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 2 organizations (IHE Delft and CMU) benefitted by the TMT
31-03-2021: 3 universities including CMU and one private industry which was the venue of the field trip.

title.narrative: B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study

comment.narrative: 31-03-2021: This information is not available yet. We could do a follow up and ask the participants for updates on their job status and how the employer has recognized the skills learnt by attending this TMT.

B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

comment.narrative: 14-04-2021: It will be nice if a standard online TMT course evaluation form is provided by OKP-Nuffic. In this manner, all the awarded TMTs can be evaluated with the same criteria. For this TMT = All the participants mentioned that they have gained new skills and knowledge.

title.narrative: B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment

comment.narrative: 14-04-2021: This was NOT confirmed or verified later. We assume, by now (April 2021) that at least 30% of the TMT participants would have applied this knowledge in their teaching and/or research developments.

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative:
31-03-2021: 1) Only 15 female staff members attended the training due to the low number of female staff in the Environmental Engineering department, CMU. However, female staff members and PhD candidates from the Environmental Engineering department got the first priority to attend this training. Moreover, the female staffs from other related fields were also invited and got the first priority to attend this training. Information about the TMT was sent by email and as a poster/flyer to all head of the related departments of Chiang Mai University (CMU). The TMT facilitated good networking opportunity for IHE Delft staffs and also CMU staffs with other universities in Thailand.
2) Prof. Susanne Rotter, one of the trainers, could not attend the training in person from Berlin. Therefore, she joined by SKYPE.
3) Eldon Raj from IHE Delft also conducted a half day scientific writing workshop for PhD students of CMU and it was attended by ~15 female students.

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 2 organizations (IHE Delft and CMU) benefitted by the TMT
31-03-2021: 3 universities including CMU and one private industry which was the venue of the field trip.

title.narrative: B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study

comment.narrative: 31-03-2021: This information is not available yet. We could do a follow up and ask the participants for updates on their job status and how the employer has recognized the skills learnt by attending this TMT.

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)
B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value:
Most of the participants were interested to learn new sustainable technologies for agricultural waste to energy conversion, specifically the EU experience. They wanted to apply these technologies and skills in their job, and also in ongoing agriculture-related projects in Thailand.
Concerning changes in professional attitude: Some of the staff have integrated this new knowledge into their existing curriculum or courses. Besides, they also learnt new methods of teaching, including the use of KAHOOT, Mentimeter, etc that helped them to teach online during the COVID pandemic
​

title.narrative: B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: The trainer, Dr. Capucine Dupont (Female) was one of the trainers. She explained to students about the role of women in the engineering sectors and provided good feedback, shared her French and Asian experiences with research and innovation in the solid waste management sector.
